Is it just me or is the diagram in the thumbnail misleading? 19 year span at 5% and 24 year span at 29% and then the rest of the categories up to 85+ are 9 year spans. i love this channel but i have to say that these graphs are pretty misleading. especially the one in the thumbnail, with no labeling. but none of them emphasize at all that the 20-44 group is almost three times as many people than any other age group. i understand emphasizing that people 20-44 are still at risk but this distorts the data into seemingly showing more cases/hospitalizations/deaths where there aren't. a better way to present it would be to show the percentages for each nine year age group and another, maybe shaded or separate, figure showing the cases for the "young people" group. essentially, it's misleading to show data with mixed variables (such as small age groups and full demographics on one bar graph) and a distinction should be made. i know this isn't just ASAP, since most of the data they used had this error. especially in such a trying time, people probably won't be looking for how big each age group on the x-axis is.


for example, the graph in the thumbnail (already missing labels, so it's unclear what it represents, but i guess there isn't a lot of room in a thumbnail) shows 29% of whatever being from the age group 20-44. if there were 2.7 age groups of nine years, they would average at around 11% of the total whatever. this would make each age group (and the demographic as a whole) at a significant lower risk of whatever compared to the next three age groups. this graph could cause unnecessary panic to someone in the 20-44 age demographic if not read very carefully enough. there's other ways to interpret the graph, but without labels it would seem to a normal person like me that it is supposed to represent cases, hospitalizations, or deaths compared to the whole population since that is what most headline graphs show nowadays.


this doesn't apply to representing something similar to the percent of deaths in cases from a single age group (such as x% of the cases in 20-29 year olds resulted in hospitalization) or something unrelated to the total population. maybe i'm just an idiot, but it's not like any of us have anywhere to be.

If you're a young person in America, you should be afraid. Even if you're still covered by your parent's insurance thanks to Obama, if you get hospitalized due to COVID-19 the out of pocket costs of insurance can easily be more than you make in an entire year or two. If parts of the treatment get considered out-of network or you don't have insurance at all, then look forward to a debt you might never be able to pay back - especially with how job prospects are looking right now. So just because you might not end up in the small group of young people that dies doesn't mean you'll necessarily avoid the larger group which gets sick enough for a week-long hospital stay that could ruin your future.


Right now, a few specific insurance companies (not all) have made moves to try to prevent this and the government has talked of maybe trying to force something on hospitals to help with surprise bills - but these patchwork solutions are full of holes and not guaranteed to help everyone. Considering America's track record with medical costs, it is probably best for young people here to act with the assumption that they cannot afford to go to the hospital and take every preventative measure to avoid getting COVID-19 in the first place to avoid having to do so.

As a public health specialist, I need to point out some important biases in your analysis. All your estimation use the DIAGNOSED number of cases as the denominator. Recent data suggest that a large part of infected cases remain undetected. When I say large, I mean potentially huge. In Europe, fist studies using serological tests (to see a past infection) suggest that up up 10-15% of individuals in cluster have been infected. This means that up to 90-95% of cases are undiagnosed which would radically changes the odds you presented. Will some under 49 people die of COVID19? Absolutely !! Infect a sufficient large number of individuals and you will have some dead even with a minuscule risk. This is why COVID19 is a huge public health issue given the huge number of potentially infected individuals. The question at hand is what is the individual risk compared to other daily risk that we are exposed to. This is what will shape our perception. As a side note, with no vaccine before the end of 2021 and likely no miracle drug, the only way to protect the more at risk individuals in our society might be to constitute herd immunity i.e. infected everybody at low risk. I’m currently publishing a Covid19 simulation model that shows just that to inform quarantine lifting in France. I can share the manuscript if you are interested.

Directions

Prep

Cook

Ready In
